Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cyber-Constructor: Enhancing spatial and temporal cognitive ability in construction education through augmented reality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many problems in construction management involve complex spatial reasoning in an environment that changes continuously until the project is complete. However, the ability of construction management students to solve these spatial-temporal problems is hampered by their lack of exposure to construction processes on the job-site, and a lack of appropriate pedagogical materials hinders instructors' ability to bring on-site experiences into construction courses. Hence, many students do not develop an understanding of the dynamic, complex spatial constraints (e.g., how construction products are related to one another in a particular contextual space) and the temporal constraints (e.g., the dependencies for coordinating subcontractors' processes).

This project uses Augmented Reality Technology (ART) as an instructional mechanism to incorporate virtual job-site visits through the combination of two layers (the real environment and the computer-generated information). ART enhances the physical, real-world environment through computer-generated sensory input. ART enables students to enhance their perception of the job-site and, more importantly, allows them unlimited access to otherwise limited opportunities to participate in job-site experiences. This research investigates the use of virtual objects and geometric models to enhance the understanding of products within construction processes by boosting a student's spatial and temporal cognition skills. The project is creating instructional modules using ART for to be used within the construction management curriculum on two campuses: The University of Florida and Florida International University. By using control and treatment groups for each module, the project is assessing the effects of using ART on students' spatial-temporal skills as well as their problem solving skills. These skills are being assessed using validated instruments administered by an independent evaluator.

Performance_Institution.Name: Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout the project lifecycle, the PI at Louisiana State University (LSU) has been collaborating with the research team at the University of Florida (UF) for data collection. 91 data sets were collected in Fall 2015 and Spring 2016 from an estimating class at LSU for the experiment of using augmented reality technologies, 79 of which were used in analysis. In addition, the PI also developed and tested a simulation environment based on the structure-behavior-function (SBF) theory for learning estimating concepts and processes. One hundred nine students participated in the test of the simulation environment in Fall 2015.

While collaborating with the UF team on developing and testing a learning environment using the augmented reality technology (ART), the LSU team explored the relationship between understanding actual processes of construction and the learning of abstract concepts of a specific construction topic such as estimating. To determine the connection between the cognitive processes of learning a particular topic and actual construction information, the team at LSU hypothesizes that a simulation developed based on the SBF theory can help students develop better problem-solving approaches in learning.  

The purpose of the simulation is to test if by connecting the learning of abstract concepts in estimating with concrete concepts of construction processes, students will develop a better understanding about an estimating process and thus a better approach to estimating. For students who have not learned estimating, the concept of estimating is abstract. A demonstration of how to detail this abstract concept is thus key. The simulation developed based on the SBF theory treats a construction process and its corresponding estimate as two systems and the process of developing an estimate as the behavior of an estimating process. Through such a demonstration, the functions of each system and its elements are illustrated as well. Major results from the experiments include:

  1. The descriptive data showed that most of the students in the experimental group found the simulation helpful or very helpful in understanding cost items, the relationship between productivity and installation cost, a typical estimating process or how to relate actual construction to conceptual processes in estimating. Only a small portion of the students responded that the simulation was not helpful and about 10% of the students thought the tool was extremely helpful. Overall, it is reasonable to conclude that the students had a very positive perception about the usefulness of the simulation.
  2. It can be concluded based on statistical analysis that the simulation based on the SBF theory helped the students learn estimating concepts and processes and techniques, and impacted their short-term memory positively. However, it appears that the students had some pre-conceived knowledge about estimating and its processes, which makes it difficult for the simulation to change their pre-existing concepts in a short period of time.
  3. In addition, although students were not limited in the number of times they could use the simulation before answering questions, most of them only went through the simulation once. The lack of repetitions may have contributed to the failure in changing the pre-conception in a short period of time. This observation also explains the existence of inconsistent answers among students who had used the simulation.

This research has shown a new approach to teach construction estimating by focusing on connecting construction processes with abstract concepts through simulation. Such an approach can be applied to other subjects as well.
